Saigo.Action: Reads a letter describing the strategic digging of defensive holes to prepare for battle, demonstrating awareness of tactical necessities.
Notes the limited space of the holes dug (only big enough to stand), showing a clear understanding of constraints and defensive tactics.
Expresses frustration about the island, calling it unpleasant and suggesting giving it to the Americans.
Stops grumbling and formally salutes the captain upon being addressed, showing respect for authority.
Complains loudly about the harsh conditions and expresses defeatist views openly in front of officers.
Ignores a peer's warning to be careful about what he says in front of a superior officer.
Upon being confronted by Captain Tanida, quickly corrects his statement and renders a respectful salute despite prior grumbling.
Watches other soldiers eat hungrily while not eating himself.
Makes a toast to General Kuribayashi, praising him as a fine commander.
Corrects Nozaki firmly but with some condescension, calling his ears 'full of wax'.
Expresses trust in General Kuribayashi’s leadership and confidence in his strategy.
Stands to attention attentively during new orders briefing.
Mutters 'Damn Kuribayashi!' when dirt falls on his back while digging under harsh conditions
Laughs embarrassedly when teased by Private Yamazaki about his letters, responds with a playful retort 'Nosey'.
Raises voice in protest when Private Yamazaki censors his letter, but ultimately shares a laugh with him.
Laughs embarrassedly when informed about mail delivery delays and continues to write many letters despite the obstacles.
Allows Private Yamazaki to censor his letters without insisting or intervening.
Grumbles quietly after Private Yamazaki censors his letter, showing passive acceptance but no confrontation.
Bows his head in apology when reprimanded by Captain Tanida.
Jerks his gun last minute and misses the target badly during rifle practice.
Fails a second attempt at shooting accurately and is reprimanded as an embarrassment and poor soldier.
Accepts punishment without arguing or showing defiance, bows his head in apology.
Continues cleaning shoes diligently without looking up, despite Kashiwara's comment about his shooting skill.
Admits to having no aim when asked about his shooting ability.
Organizes and helps tear down a schoolhouse to collect wood for practical use.
Shares a picture from a book with Nozaki and starts a friendly conversation about it.
Reads a book with pictures of Egypt and shares knowledge or observations with Nozaki.
Tries to prevent Shimizu from putting his bedroll in his deceased friend's spot, showing respect for Kashiwara's memory.
Dismisses Shimizu's placement and insists Shimizu use another space, indirectly expressing grief but also distancing himself emotionally.
Makes bleak statements about death and the futility of war, which may come across as pessimistic or unsupportive.
Continuing to read his book quietly, ignoring social greetings and interactions, which may indicate detachment or lack of engagement with others.
Insists on placing Shimizu's bedroll at the back end of the cave to respect his deceased friend Kashiwara’s spot.
Continues reading his book despite interruptions and the arrival of new recruits, showing focus and calm.
Makes fatalistic statements about death and the plan to die, which could undermine morale or confidence.
Shares personal story about bakery loss and expresses regret thoughtfully.
Motions towards Shimizu silently after comment, avoiding confrontation or blame.
Suppresses shock and eats without comment when confronted with a difficult situation.
Clearly recounts his past business and war effort contributions, showing self-awareness about his reduced circumstances.
Reflects on lost bakery business due to wartime shortages and requisitions without taking apparent action to adapt or resist.
Sits calmly reading a book when informed of being drafted, showing composure.
Expresses regret about profession choice ('I should have been a fisherman') implying resignation rather than proactive mindset.
Bows to the women delivering the red letter and expresses gratitude, showing respect and humility.
Tells Hanako to go to the back during confrontation, showing protective behavior.
Acknowledges Hanako’s distress and inability to eat, shows concern.
Comforts Hanako when she expresses fear about his possible death and the baby’s future.
Whispers to the unborn baby to reassure Hanako, showing tenderness and hope.
Takes the red letter and bows respectfully despite turning pale, showing composure under emotional stress.
Expresses willingness to serve the nation confidently.
Tries to comfort Hanako by physically showing affection and speaking optimistically about returning.
Does not engage in conflict when Hanako argues or expresses fear, chooses to support quietly instead.
Uses gentle humor to deflect Hanako's despair (Am I already in the coffin?), showing mental resilience.
Works alongside others in difficult and hazardous conditions wearing gas masks, contributing to tunnel excavation and preparation.
Does not appear or act in this excerpt; no direct behaviors to evaluate competence.
Sits attentively during the instructional lecture led by Captain Tanida, exchanging looks of distrust with Nozaki towards Shimizu's simplistic assessment of American soldiers.
Does not speak or challenge Shimizu’s claim about American soldiers openly, despite apparent distrust.
Quickly takes cover behind a large rock formation during an air raid, demonstrating awareness and survival skill under attack.
Stands at attention and listens respectfully to Kuribayashi’s motivational speech over the loudspeaker, showing discipline and readiness.
No direct actions or statements indicating independent initiative or skill are evident in the excerpt; primarily being a passive listener.
Places his money into an envelope with other soldiers, contributing to letters and valuables, showing concern for loved ones
Boasts to Nozaki about his thousand-stitch cotton belt making him untouchable.
Puts on a heavily stitched cotton belt and confidently boasts to Nozaki that no one can shoot him now.
Engages in light banter about the superstition of the belts, showing awareness of morale and soldier psychology.
Reluctantly obeys Captain Tanida's order to carry out the unpleasant task of emptying the shit pot.
Expresses disgust while handling the chamber pot but still performs the task diligently.
Tries to retrieve the dropped chamber pot despite the difficulty.
Despite danger, carefully retrieves the bowl from the crevice with determination, then runs to safety with relief.
Expresses frustration and anger toward God for their suffering.
After the dud shell, thanks God sincerely and acknowledges greatness.
Watches night flares and shares nostalgic memories of home with Shimizu, including details about children building snow houses and warm traditions.
Drifts off to sleep on night guard duty and needs nudging to wake up and attend to his rifle.
Falls asleep momentarily while on night guard duty, hand slipping off his rifle until nudged awake by Shimizu.
Wakes up quickly and promptly picks up his rifle after being alerted.
Stretches and goes to the cave opening to observe the night flares, showing awareness of surroundings.
Engages in reflective and somewhat emotional conversation with Shimizu, showing distraction but also maintaining some situational awareness.
Tells Shimizu he is good at keeping secrets when Shimizu seems hesitant.
Rushed to aid Ozawa immediately after he was hit.
Clumsily tries to use his rifle instead of accepting Tanida's order, accidentally points gun at Tanida and apologizes.
Feels inwardly triumphant when assigned to run report instead of fighting.
Offers to keep secrets confidential, showing social awareness and discretion.
Attempts to operate a rifle but clumsily points it at his superior and is called an imbecile.
Follows orders to deliver a report requesting another machine gun without hesitation.
Arrives at Col. Adachi's cave promptly and waits silently for instructions, showing discipline and readiness to support leadership.
Does not attempt to intervene or question the situation when Col. Adachi requests permission for a suicide mission, indicating deference but potentially lack of initiative.
Takes the note of mass suicide to his commander despite the grim content, shows willingness to communicate difficult orders.
Complies quietly with Captain Tanida’s command to sit down after trying to speak on the General’s order to escape.
Does not resist or openly challenge orders leading to mass suicide, passes along orders rather than intervening.
Takes the note from Col. Adachi and promptly carries out the order to deliver it to the commander despite the grim content.
Attempts to question and seek clarification from General Kuribayashi when given a harsh order, indicating initiative and concern.
Passively complies with the difficult circumstances without showing proactive leadership or a clear plan to change the course.
Withdraws quietly after handing the note instead of motivating or supporting the men under his influence.
Retreats from a suicidal grenade blast and chooses to run for an outlet, seeking survival and regrouping.
Persuades Shimizu to abandon a suicidal order by citing credible information from General Kuribayashi, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Navigates the network of caves confidently, knowing it will take them closer to Motoyama.
Responds succinctly to other soldiers about the status of his men, indicating clear and honest communication.
Pulls Ono back to protect him from grenade blast.
Turns away, unable to watch the beating and killing of the American marine.
Pulls Ono back with him to avoid grenade blast, saving himself and Ono.
Suggests finding another route and returning to Suribachi after the tunnel is blocked.
Turns away, unable to watch the brutal killing of the American Marine.
Advises Shimizu to avoid running with the herd and to stay low to minimize casualties during a risky escape.
Demonstrates practical battlefield awareness by prioritizing survival and caution over reckless bravery.
Straggles behind during the charge rather than rushing forward, indicating a focus on careful movement.
Does not challenge the chaotic plan to make a desperate charge, but tries to mitigate harm through personal action.
Commands men to take cover and crawl forward carefully under heavy fire, demonstrating tactical caution and awareness.
Times the rush forward to coincide with flares dying out to avoid enemy fire, showing situational intelligence and skill.
Keeps calm and issues clear orders during a chaotic, violent engagement, reflecting leadership and confidence.
Advances with his sword to defend himself against Lt. Ito's harsh punishment.
Trembling and obeys by falling to his knees despite his fear.
Advances with his sword to defend himself against Lt. Ito's order to kneel.
Falls to his knees trembling after being ordered by Lt. Ito, showing submission despite his initial resistance.
Escapes Mt. Suribachi contrary to traditional expectation of dying in position.
Questions the soldier's order by reminding that General Kuribayashi’s orders are to remain in the caves.
Snoring heavily after ordeals, showing fatigue or lack of alertness.
Muttering 'We're dead' immediately as the attack begins, indicating a lack of confidence or fatalism.
Crouching behind rocks and staying pinned down under heavy fire alongside others, showing tactical awareness of battlefield cover.
Whispers to Shimizu 'Never trust a captain that tries to cut your head off.'
Suggests not trusting a captain who tries to cut your head off, implying skepticism of poor leadership.
Successfully operates a spigot mortar with Shimizu, contributing to the destruction of three American tanks.
Assigned to strenuous and important duties under heavy combat pressure and appears capable in execution.
No direct action or statement by Saigo shown in the excerpt
Stops to listen attentively to the letter from a fellow soldier's mother, showing respect and empathy
Calls for Medic Endo to attend to injured Baron Nishi promptly
Quickly responds to an emergency by calling for Medic Endo when Baron Nishi is injured.
Attempts to reload and carry a mortar under heavy shelling despite the danger.
No hesitation shown in combat, calmly continuing to engage the enemy despite chaos.
Organizes and lines up men in formation, ready to move out efficiently.
Expresses hope and encouragement with 'They’ve got to make it' when soldiers attempt to retrieve water under dangerous conditions.
Expresses frustration and hopelessness openly, admits desire to surrender and challenges authority.
Shows anger towards Shimizu but reveals vulnerability by sharing his inner turmoil.
Does not act violently or harshly toward others despite frustration, indicating restrained behavior.
Expresses frustration and declares intent to surrender after the loss of precious water supplies.
Shows emotional outburst and challenges Shimizu angrily rather than strategizing or seeking solutions.
Watches passively as valuable water is lost with no indication of attempting to protect or salvage it.
Comforts Shimizu after his dismissal by making a lighthearted comment and sharing a chuckle.
Comforts Shimizu after his dismissal, encourages him to maintain morale.
Shows awareness and emotional intelligence by lightening the mood despite difficult circumstances.
Grovels with the men on the ground sharing the uncooked rice despite harsh conditions
Expresses that the current suffering is not fit for a human being, showing empathy
Does not display leadership or attempt to comfort others explicitly in the excerpt
Gobbles down uncooked rice with the other soldiers in the cave, choking on it and showing physical weakness.
Sits on the ground coughing, expressing that the current life is not what a human being should suffer.
Shares a compassionate and sincere perspective on life and death, encouraging Shimizu to appreciate life's beauty before sacrificing it.
Remains silent when Shimizu expresses doubts and fears, but later responds with empathy and understanding.
Offers Shimizu a thoughtful perspective that questions blind obedience and values life experience over death in battle.
Remains silent initially when Shimizu asks for his opinion, potentially showing hesitation or reluctance to engage directly.
Does not take any direct action toward changing their dire situation or leading the men, instead focusing on philosophical reflection.
Picks up Shimizu's lucky belt gravely, showing respect and care for his comrade's belongings.
Follows after Shimizu and Kanda trying to understand their behavior, offers a gentle explanation to Okubo that they might have been spooked.
Looks crestfallen after Kanda is shot, showing emotional sensitivity to the violence and loss.
Drops into the ditch immediately upon seeing his friend's dead body and picks up Shimizu’s body.
No direct action, statement, or internal behavior attributed to Saigo in this excerpt.
Rushes forward nervously in a zig-zag motion to dodge bullets, helping his troop cross safely to cave.
Appears as a member of a struggling group with no officers, silent about leadership loss.
Runs forward nervously in a zig-zag motion, successfully dodging bullets.
Manages to cross through dangerous enemy fire and reaches safety along with other troops.
Appears dirty, haggard, and suffering from malnutrition, indicating physical and mental strain.
Writes a heartfelt letter acknowledging difficult conditions but shows concern and responsibility for family and comrades.
Attempts to maintain morale among dejected men by resting with them patiently.
No visible initiative or strategic action to improve dire situation (starvation, dehydration, low morale).
Brings a pitiful plate of worms to share despite scarcity.
Humbly downplays his own importance when complimented by Kuribayashi.
Shares about his family and personal life openly with Kuribayashi.
Shows willingness to listen and engage politely by staying to hear Chinese poetry despite not knowing much about it.
Listens quietly to Kuribayashi's poetry and controls his emotions respectfully.
Appears especially disheartened during the speech about a certain death mission.
Obeys Kuribayashi’s order without hesitation, despite apparent surprise.
Carefully burns all sensitive documents entrusted to him, showing reliability and sincerity.
Leads a force of about 300 men, though poorly equipped, showing ability to organize and command under difficult circumstances.
Follows Kuribayashi's orders to burn all important documents, executing the task dutifully and efficiently.
Expresses surprise when ordered to remain behind while others leave, indicating possible uncertainty or momentary lack of readiness for unexpected commands.
Notices Kuribayashi’s sketches falling to the floor and takes note of them before continuing to burn documents.
Finds a leather satchel full of undelivered mail and Kuribayashi’s sketches, contemplates burning it but stops and decides to bury it instead, using a shovel to dig a hole.
Successfully buries the mail and sketches to preserve them despite chaos around.
Witnesses Fujita's death and falls to his knees in shock, approaches dying Kuribayashi with respect and attentiveness.
Responds sincerely and respectfully to Kuribayashi's questions and requests in a moment of great distress.
Hears Kuribayashi's yells and quickly heads towards the clearing, showing attentiveness and readiness to assist.
Becomes shocked and falls to his knees upon witnessing Fujita's death, showing a moment of emotional overwhelm.
Approaches the dying Kuribayashi and responds appropriately to his questions, showing respect and presence of mind.
Affirms to Kuribayashi that they have not yet surrendered, maintaining morale and clarity.
Digs a grave and respectfully buries the dead General Kuribayashi, bows after covering the grave.
Drags Kuribayashi’s body to a chosen burial site and digs a grave with a shovel despite struggling physically.
Quickly finishes covering the grave after hearing the explosion and bows respectfully.
Waves shovel at Marines, ready to fight despite being unarmed and overwhelmed
Glances back towards his General’s body before confronting the Marines
Says 'Hanako, now I know what it feels like to dig my own grave.' with kind eyes and energetic demeanor.
Acknowledges the grim reality of digging holes to stand in until death.
Shows clear understanding of General Kuribayashi's strategy by explaining that he studied the Americans to know how to beat them.
Encourages confidence in leadership by toasting Kuribayashi and dismissing rumors about lack of trench digging, indicating awareness of troop morale and strategy.
Dismisses information from other soldiers as untrustworthy or unreliable, showing some critical judgment.
Speaks confidently but somewhat bluntly, which could risk alienating others (calling Nozaki stupid), hinting at possible social or emotional shortcomings rather than a pure competence issue.
Removes all air attack force plans from the strategic table model and contemplates the lack of air support seriously.
Acts confused or in disbelief about the loss of Combined Fleet and naval air power initially.
Approaches Yamazaki and urges him to help clean up despite Yamazaki being gravely wounded or dead.
Shares concern with Nozaki about Shimizu possibly reporting on them but tries to reassure him calmly.
Estimates the size of the enemy fleet accurately (at least 30, maybe even 50 ships).
Reluctantly follows orders despite disgust and unpleasantness (carrying and disposing of chamber pot).
Carefully navigates around dangerous terrain to dispose of chamber pot, showing caution and awareness.
Drops and loses the chamber pot while startled by the massive armada, then fails to retrieve it.
Runs between interconnected caves supplying ammunition during intense fighting.
Commands men to keep down and crawl forward under fire, coordinating movements to minimize casualties.
Uses clear and calm communication during lethal combat situations to protect his men.
Exhibits no visible signs of harshness or disregard for others’ safety despite the chaos.
Primarily focused on tactical commands with limited explicit expression of personal care or emotion toward comrades.
Sees the body of his friend Shimizu, drops into the ditch and picks up his pale and lifeless body.
Is in tears upon seeing the body of his friend, showing emotional vulnerability.
Looks numb and listless as the soldiers trudge on, indicating emotional withdrawal or despair.
Expresses eternal gratitude sincerely to Kuribayashi for saving his life twice.
Writes a heartfelt letter to Hanako, expressing worries about family and comfort in communicating despite dire circumstances.
Stops himself from burning the undelivered letters and Kuribayashi’s sketches, then carefully buries them in a leather satchel.
